title: Ticket #6468: Memory handling issues in python bindings when using projections
description:
This ticket cleans up memory management bugs in the Python bindings with respect to STL vectors. These bugs result in ASSERTS being thrown by the standard C library on Windows when using query functions with projections, and I suppose could result in the memory of the Python process being trashed.

The problem was in several places in the Python binding implementation, the following idiom was used: 

  std::vector<xxx> array;
  array.reserve(max);
  for (x=0; x<max; x++) {
     array[x] = ....
  }
In the above code, the reserve() method was used instead of the resize() method. This is a problem because reserve() alone is not sufficient to start referencing vectors by index, as no vector entries were actually created.

Turns out the patch to fix these incidents does not bother with calling resize(), because in most cases the use of an STL vector wasn't required and thus the errant code was simply removed. In other cases, push_back() was used.
